choices.D: 802.11ac is not backward compatible with 802.11a or 802.11n.
choices.A: 802.11ac is backward compatible with 802.11n but not with 802.11a.
choices.B: 802.11ac is backward compatible with 802.11a but not with 802.11n.

questions.question_text: An engineer must assess an existing company WLAN to determine the possibility for future IEEE 802.11ac Wave 2 wireless deployment. The existing WLAN is IEEE 802.11a/n and has IEEE 802.11n and 802. 11a clients. The engineer must advise the customer about support for these older clients on the new APs. What happens with client compatibility?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Given answer is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-802-11ac.html#~q-a
Option C is right if the client's 802.11n adapter supports 5 GHz. Many do not.

choices.B: The edge of the cell should be below 35 RSSI.
choices.A: The edge of the cell should be גˆ’67 dBm.
choices.C: The measurement should be done on the 2.4-GHz band.
choices.D: One AP should be deployed per 3000 square feet.

questions.question_text: An engineer must decide the cell overlap for a wireless voice deployment. Which Cisco measurement recommendation should be considered?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
minimum power of -67 dBm on the cell boundary

Selected Answer: A
Guidelines for deploying 802.11b VoWLAN handsets have recommended a design with a minimum power of -67 dBm on the cell boundary

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Mobility/emob30dg/Voice.pdf

Guidelines for deploying 802.11b VoWLAN handsets have recommended a design with a minimum power of -67 dBm on the cell boundary

The optimal VoWLAN network requires overlaps of 20 percent (2.4 GHz), and approximately 15 to 20 percent (5 GHz), where a WLAN Data design may use an AP cell overlap of 5 to 10 percent.

•The optimal VoWLAN cell boundary recommendation is -67 dBm
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Mobility/vowlan/41dg/vowlan41dg-book/vowlan_ch3.html

Selected Answer: D
The RX-SOP threshold setting determines the minimum signal level that a wireless device will consider as a valid signal to decode.
By adjusting the RX-SOP threshold to a higher value, the APs will ignore weaker signals, effectively reducing the cell size. This ensures that clients connect to the nearest AP with the strongest and highest quality signal, thereby using higher data rates.
A higher RX-SOP threshold minimizes interference from distant APs and forces clients to roam more aggressively to closer APs with stronger signals.

The question didn't mentioned it's a cisco equipment 
"RX-SOP " feature available for Cisco only

questions.question_text: An engineer is setting up the WLC to support a high-density design for a lecture hall. The engineer must modify the existing high-density RF profile to obtain a smaller cell size. Also, the clients must connect to the nearest AP using the highest possible data rates. Which setting allows this design?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
On the 9800 WLC, control plane encryption is always enabled, which means that you need to have secure mobility enabled on the AireOS side. However, data link encryption is optional. If you enable it on the 9800 side, enable it on AireOS with: config mobility group member data-dtls enable

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/213913-building-mobility-tunnels-on-catalyst-98.html

Selected Answer: A
Need to correct my previous answer , A is correct .

Selected Answer: B
Provided answer is correct.

"AireOS uses EoIP tunnels for mobility. Support for CAPWAP based encrypted mobility (Secure Mobility) was brought in in 8.5. However the support for IRCM with Catalyst 9800 wireless controller is present only in 8.8.111 and above and in the 8.5 IRCM supported release."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/technotes/8-8/b_c9800_wireless_controller-aireos_ircm_dg.html#id_85243
Question is tricky because 9800s don't support EoIP tunnel, only UDP 16667 for data.
B is correct , encryption of the control plane regarding 5520 is required. for 9800 we dont need to enable encryption for control plan as it is enabled by default

questions.question_text: An engineer designs a new wireless network that uses a Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series wireless controller. The controller must be in a DMZ. The internal network is to be at the main on-premises data center of the customer. In addition, the customer wants to establish an EoIP tunnel to a Cisco 5520 WLC that is in a regional office. How must this requirement be incorporated into the design?

choices.A: Use Cisco IOS-XE code that supports encryption of the data plane on the Catalyst 9800 WLC.
choices.D: Use AirOS code that supports encryption of the data plane on the 5520 WLC.
choices.B: Use AirOS code that supports encryption of the control plane on the 5520 WLC.
choices.C: Use Cisco IOS-XE code that supports encryption of the control plane on the Catalyst 9800 WLC.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct

D and E are right choice. Reducing the channel width to 20 MHz increases the number of available non-overlapping channels, helping to avoid interference with nearby APs.Reducing the transmit power of the AP can help minimize the overlap between adjacent APs' coverage areas,

questions.question_text: An engineer must deploy a wireless network in an open-plan environment that has three SSIDs using the 5 GHz band and the channel width is set to 40 MHz. Co-channel interference must be reduced. Which two actions must be taken? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Reduce the power of the AP.
choices.D: Decrease channel bonding in the 5 GHz band to 20 MHz.
choices.B: Increase channel bonding in the 2.4 GHz band to 40 MHz.
